learning_outcomes.description: Analyse how social, historical, cultural, and political forces shape the form, practice, and lived experience of various forms of punishment across diverse contexts.
Evaluate research addressing the implications and effects of punishment for individuals and communities.
Construct clear, reasoned arguments about punishment and society that are appropriate for diverse audiences and settings.
Create and justify alternative approaches to punishment that address limitations in current systems.

assessments.task_description:
The seminar program is designed to encourage your active engagement with and critical reflection on the course content. Seminars are held in-person on the St Lucia Campus at the scheduled time. Seminars will include small-group, pair, and class discussion, role-play and problem-solving activities. 

In four designated weeks (weeks 3, 6, 9 and 12), students will be assessed for their completion of a discussion worksheet. The worksheets pose questions that ask you to reflect on the discussion in the room as well as your understanding of the readings and lectures. The word length for each paper is up to 500 words each (2000 words overall, across 4 papers).

Seminar-related questions to be addressed on the worksheet will be released during the seminars. This means you must attend the seminar to receive the worksheet questions.

Note that you are responsible for the material covered in all seminars. Seminar questions posed in each designated week can refer to the current and/or earlier seminars.  

You are also highly encouraged to draw on course readings, lectures, your own critical reasoning, and - when prompted - to also source external resources, when completing the worksheets. Details are provided in the marking rubric. Marking criteria and/or marking rubrics are available in the ‘Assessment’ folder in Blackboard for this course. 

Each discussion worksheet is worth 12.5% of your overall grade (50% for all four worksheets, overall).

The Use of AI: This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which AI will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference AI use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. Students must complete an AI usage declaration and submit it with their assessment. Additional resources are available through UQ AI Student Hub.

See Blackboard for further details about this assessment.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You must submit your assignment electronically by the due time, on the due date. Ensure you use the course assignment template for all four submissions.

assessments.task_description:
A short-answer examination will be scheduled for the Central Exam period (after end of semester). This short-answer exam will assess your knowledge of material presented in lectures, discussions and readings over the course of the entire semester. The purpose of the exam is to give you the opportunity to demonstrate knowledge of the relevant skills and theories to which you have been exposed during the course.

Your exam will include short-answer essay questions and will be open-book. You will be able to take in notes, learning resources, and other materials to help you answer the exam questions.

The Use of AI: This assessment task will be completed in-person. The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted.

Further details about the exam, as well as advice for exam preparation, will be delivered to students during the semester. Students should also note that assignment 1 (series of short-answer worksheets) is designed to build skills towards the successful completion of this end-of-semester exam.
